page.title: 02Farming near Shipton
page.content: Shipton used to be quite a self-supporting village with it's Cobbler's shop, Blacksmith, Wheelwright and its bakery back in the 1920's when all the villagers lived and worked locally . The majority of the labourers were either shepherds, herdsmen or grooms. There were also general workers or day-men, employed in thatching, ditching, hedging and stone walling, so that as many as twenty men were employed on one farm alone.The highest wages for the head-men being 10/- per week. Women were employed on the farms in the summer time,raking the hay, tying sheaves and stooking them. Other jobs for women were stone-picking, hoeing, clearing the wheat fields of sheaves and gleaning with the children after the harvest had been collected.
